channel.title: C++
channel.description: Well, i wanted to know if C++ is hard to learn... the reason i ask is i have to code part of a project in it and it only requires basic C++ knowledge for that part of the project.

item.title: C++
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“SETO, post:7, topic:390015”]if you are comming from any OOP programming lang, you might not find it easy.
Have fun with memory management[/quote]

what?

C++ has good support for object oriented programming, i don’t see why it’s that much different from any other language that supports OOP. yeah, you have to understand a bit about internal memory and pointers etc. but overall it’s not that different from Java, the only really big thing missing is the garbage collector so you have to clean up memory on your own.

Read full topic

item.title: C++
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

if you are comming from any OOP programming lang, you might not find it easy.
Have fun with memory management

item.title: C++
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:5, topic:390015”][quote author=_s link=topic=485928.msg3561000#msg3561000 date=1302277227]
C++ isn’t too hard a language to learn, i feel the harder parts for beginners are the OOP-related concepts as well as getting your head around templates and some of the more obscure things you can do with them like metaprogramming, specialisation etc.
[/quote]

Another thing I’ve noticed about people who try to jump into C/C++ is the use of pointers.[/quote]

C style pointers aren’t a hard concept and they’re slowly becoming deprecated in C++, just look at smart pointers being introduced to the language and references exist too which are a safer and friendlier alternative to pointers.

Read full topic

item.title: C++
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

_s:

C++ isn’t too hard a language to learn, i feel the harder parts for beginners are the OOP-related concepts as well as getting your head around templates and some of the more obscure things you can do with them like metaprogramming, specialisation etc.

Another thing I’ve noticed about people who try to jump into C/C++ is the use of pointers.

Read full topic
